sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for ǧāʔ inflection: 3SG.M 3.SG.F in PFV

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Very old speakers (70+) and some old speakers use ǧat / žat or ʔižat / ʔiǧat.
Very old speakers (70+) and some old speakers use ǧat / žat or ʔižat / ʔiǧat or ʔižit.
Very old speakers (70+) use ǧat / žat or ʔižat / ʔiǧat.
Most middle age and young people use ʔižit but not only, occassionally also older speakers.

Pickett (2005:226-227) notes: "The raising of ā in 'he came' however is a clear dialect marker distinguishing the Lebanese and closely related smaller Syrian tribes from the (Aniza, Šammar, ʕumūr and Euphrates tribal dialects described above".

Pickett (2005:226-227) notes: "The raising of ā in 'he came' however is a clear dialect marker distinguishing the Lebanese and closely related smaller Syrian tribes from the (Aniza, Šammar, ʕumūr and Euphrates tribal dialects described above".

Pickett (2005:226-227) notes: "The raising of ā in 'he came' however is a clear dialect marker distinguishing the Lebanese and closely related smaller Syrian tribes from the (Aniza, Šammar, ʕumūr and Euphrates tribal dialects described above".

Pickett (2005:226-227) notes: "The raising of ā in 'he came' however is a clear dialect marker distinguishing the Lebanese and closely related smaller Syrian tribes from the (Aniza, Šammar, ʕumūr and Euphrates tribal dialects described above".

Pickett (2005:226-227) notes: "The raising of ā in 'he came' however is a clear dialect marker distinguishing the Lebanese and closely related smaller Syrian tribes from the (Aniza, Šammar, ʕumūr and Euphrates tribal dialects described above".

Pickett (2005:226-227) notes: "The raising of ā in 'he came' however is a clear dialect marker distinguishing the Lebanese and closely related smaller Syrian tribes from the (Aniza, Šammar, ʕumūr and Euphrates tribal dialects described above".
only for North Central group
only used by the speakers of texts B and C
deducted from examples
Belinkov (2019) recorded one older speaker who used ǧā without the inital a
preferred form for third person with vowel-inital suffixes
more commonly used form
Maltese orthography: ġiet
The third person is always a communis, thus the originally male forms ja/ji can also be used here.
men's speech
women's speech
The northern dialects of Ṣaʕdah have ʔatan, the other dialects yit/yat
The northern dialects of Ṣaʕdah have ʔatan, the other dialects yit/yat
The northern dialects of Ṣaʕdah have ʔatan, the other dialects yit/yat
masculine: ǧē
